The 'maxRetries' setting controls how many times a single URI will be 
returned to the frontier after a failed processing attempt to later 
retrying. But, importantly, some normal operations count as a temporary 
failure, so for example even if nothing goes wrong, a URI might get 1-2 
retries used up when it gets deferred to allow DNS or robots refresh 
fetches to occur. Thus this value should never be below 3 for normal 
operation, and if you want any robustness against occasional/transient 
network problems, could be significantly higher.

The default value of '30', together with the retryDelay of '900' (15 
minutes), means that even a network outage (near the crawler, or near 
the target server) of 30*15m = ~7.5 hours won't cause a URI to be marked 
as a total failure.

- Gordon @ IA

On 12/9/10 8:40 AM, Zach Bailey wrote:
>
>
> Does this property really do what it says? I'm concerned it's limiting
> the amount of content being downloaded from a seed.
>
> Just to clarify, I'm crawling some domain lists where some domains may
> not even have an A record, and some may not have web servers running on
> them (but they DO resolve) and so I only want to try and connect to
> these domains once, otherwise the crawl runs very slowly as it retries
> over, and over, and over, and over... (with the default timeout of 20
> minutes and max retries = 30 this will take FOREVER)
>
> So I have configured the crawl in the following manner:
>
> FetchHTTP - timeoutSeconds = 5
> frontier - maxRetries = 2
>
> Does this seem to make sense for what I'm doing? What crawl statuses
> should I be looking for to determine domains that a.) don't have a DNS A
> record (I believe the code for this is -1) and b.) HTTP connect timeout
> (I would expect to see -2, -4, or -8 for this)
>
> The reason I ask is because I'm seeing a lot of -50 crawl statuses which
> the glossary indicates "appearance in logs may be a bug", so that has me
> a little worried.
>
> Happy Holidays,
> Zach
